comments:
Doxographical presentation of non-Buddhist and Buddhist philosophical schools drawing information from the Tarkajvāla (ID:5586), Prajñāpradīpaṭīkā, Tattvasaṃgraha (and °pañjikā) and Madhyamakāvatāra (ID:3726)(ID:5885). It offers summarized refutation of each of the non-Buddhist systems and of some of the Buddhist systems, and rejection of objections against Madhyamaka. It includes extensive quotes for non-Buddhist systems, and a few citations in the section on Buddhist schools (from the Abhidharmakośa (ID:3761), Madhyamakālaṃkāra (ID:3731),
Pramāṇavārttika (ID:3772), Triṃśikā, Mahāyānasaṃgraha (ID:3753) and Mahāyānasūtrālaṃkāra (ID:3746). See [WLWGS439]: 24–25
for the details. 
The section on Madhyamka does not mention the division between svātantrika and prāsaṅgika, but only delves on the division between the non-abiding view and illusionist view with regard to ultimate reality, while on the conventional level, the author refutes madhyamka adopting a system akin to yogācāra and to sautrāntika.
A synoptic tables is provided in [WLWGS439]: 23 and [UAHPCR5I]: 69-71.

The structure of the text does not follow a strict sa bcad hierarchy (as found in Phya pa’s other works). A six-fold division (not referred to as “chapters”) structures the six systems that Phya pa distinguishes – five
non-Buddhists (vaiṣṇava, śaiva, jaina, sāṃkhya, cārvaka) and the Buddhists (see [WLWGS439]: 22).

This doxography was reported by 'Gos lo tsā ba in the [MQB8JGAX] (as phyi nang gi grub mtha’) and by A khu ching in the Tho yig ([5RXEUKD9], no. 11910: phyi nang gi grub mtha’i rnam bzhag bsdus pa) ([WLWGS439]: 21). Werner points out multiple re-use of Phya pa’s doxography in Klong chen pa (ID:6062)'s Grub mtha' mdzod.
alternative_names: phya pa chos seng gi phyi nang gi grub mtha'i rnam bzhag bsdus pa
name: bde bar gshegs pa dang phyi rol pa'i gzhung rnam par 'byed pa

comments:
The colophon reports the author's name as "slob dpon pad mA" and the scribe's name as "ze'u." The author is sKyo ston (ID:4052) or Rigs pa'i ral gri (ID:4006). In the former case, the scribe is likely the same as for other works of sKyo ston, i.e., Ze'u Chos kyi rgyal mtshan (ID:6458). In the latter case, the scribe might rather be Ze'u Grags pa shes rab (ID:4065), scribe for two other works by Rigs pa'i ral gri. According to [CTSKHPIC]: 174, n. 167, this is not a work by Rigs pa'i ral gri.
BDRC identifies the author as sKyo ston for bdr:MW1PD153536, and as Ze'u Grags pa shes rab (ID:4065) for bdr:WA0XL7E18A489111E (both entries are for the same manuscript, (ID:5096), printed twice in the [ZZVAXS4X]).
alternative_names: tshe bsgrub
name: bde gshegs kun gyi snying po

comments:
The work is a mix of verses (43 verses of four lines each, v. 37 has five lines) and prose (expanding on the verses).
The text and manuscripts are described in [Q47PVAE6]: 75–76 and [A62SS59H].
It corresponds to the work listed by A khu ching as "blo ldan shes rab kyi rnam thar bstod 'grel gro lung pas mdzad pa" ([5RXEUKD9]: 507, No. 10903).
alternative_names:
'jig rten mig gcig blo ldan shes rab gyi rnam thar
bdag nyid chen po rngog lo tsa ba'i rnam par thar pa
rngog lo tsa ba chen po'i rnam thar
rngog lo tsA ba chen po'i rnam thar
blo ldan shes rab kyi rnam par thar pa
bla ma rje btsun dam pa gsang phu lo tsha ba chen po la bstod pa'i tshig le'ur byas pa’i rnam par bshad pa
name: blo ldan shes rab kyi rnam thar

comments:
In instance (ID:5044), the work is preceded to a prayer to the members of the lineage, see work (ID:5045). In instance (ID:5048), the work is followed by the start of that prayer, but the manuscript is incomplete.
In the closing verses, the author mentions "grags pa" (ID:7022), i.e., mKhan chen bSod nams grags according to a gloss in instance (ID:5044), as his teacher. This could be Rin chen bSod nams grags pa or Byang sems bSod nams grags pa.
In instance (ID:5044), the main text alternates with glosses, and the author of the glosses added two lines after the colophon, mentioning having studied mind training for three years.
alternative_names: blo sbyong don bdun ma

comments:
Topical outline of the Sambandhaparīkṣā (ID:3775). 
It likely corresponds to the "'brel brtag la sa bcad" in the list of Ral gri's writings (ID:7112), one of his three works on  the Sambandhaparīkṣā (for the other two, see (ID:5900) and (ID:5515)).

Discussed and translated in English in [WEPMCAYR].
alternative_names:
'brel pa brtag pa'i mchan dang sa bcad gnyis
'brel pa brtag pa'i don legs par bsdus pa
name: 'brel ba brtag pa'i don bsdus

comments:
Set of explanatory annotations written as interlinear notes to the base text, the Sambandha­parīkṣā­prakaraṇa (ID: 3775).
This probably corresponds to the work referred to as "'brel brtag la 'bru 'joms" in the list of Ral gri's writings (ID:7112), one of his three works on the Sambandhaparīkṣā (for the other two, see (ID:4947) and (ID:5515)).

Discussed and translated in English, together with the base text, in [WEPMCAYR].
alternative_names:
'brel ba brtag pa'i rab tu 'byed pa mchan dang sa bcad
'brel pa brtag pa'i mchan dang sa bcad gnyis
name: 'brel ba brtag pa'i mchan bu

comments:
Apart from the commentaries by Rigs pa'i ral gri (ID:4006), this is the only known Tibetan commentary on the Sambandhaparīkṣā ([WEPMCAYR]: 284)

The sa bcad of this work are published in [FIFSTZA2].
alternative_names: 'brel pa brtag pa'i rnam bshad
name: 'brel ba brtag pa'i rnam bshad nyi ma'i snying po

comments:
Short commentary on the Sambandhaparīkṣāprakaraṇa (ID:3775), following, according to the author, the auto-commentary (ID:5567) and the commentary by Vinītadeva (ID:5568).
This likely corresponds to the work referred to as "'brel brtag la ti ka" in the list of Ral gri's writings (ID:7112), one of his three works on the Sambandhaparīkṣā (for the other two, see (ID:4947) and (ID:5900)). These works are discussed in [WEPMCAYR].
alternative_names:
'brel pa rtag pa rgyan gyi me tog
saM ban d+ha pa ri k+Sha a laM ka ra puSH+pa
name: 'brel ba brtag pa rgyan gyi me tog

comments:
Commentary on Haribhadra’s Abhisamayālaṅkārālokā, with overlapping divisions into 8 sections (skabs) of the Abhisamaya and into 32 chapters that correspond to those of the Aṣṭasāhasrikā and of Haribhadra’s Abhisamayālaṅkārālokā.
In view of the colophon referring to rNgog Blo ldan shes rab, this works could correspond to the entry "gro lung lo tsha ba'i gsung bzhin bris pa'i brgyad stong 'grel pa'i ti ka" in the list of rNgog blo ldan shes rab's compositions by bCom ldan ral gri (see <<Kano 2016 [BAQ9MH4T]>>: 207, <<Schaeffer and van der Kuijp 2009 [KHA9ZVGP]>>: 273). 
It could correspond also to the work mentioned in [R894SIKE]: 403 (bye brag tu lo tsA ba chen po'i 'grel chung gi TI ka brten nas rnam par bshad pa yang brtsams |), in which case it would rely on rNgog Blo ldan shes rab's teaching in (ID: 4435) or (ID: 6050) rather than in (ID: 6048).
Karma bde legs considers this work to be a different work from the brGyad stong pa'i 'grel (ID:6734). ([HCLRANG3]: 18, n. 22)
alternative_names:
gro lung pa blo gros 'byung gnas kyis mdzad pa'i brgyad stong 'grel chen gyi bshad pa
gro lung lo tsha ba'i gsung bzhin bris pa'i brgyad stong 'grel pa'i ti ka
dpal gro lung ba chen pos mdzad pa'i 'grel chen gyi rnam bshad
'grel chen gyi rnam bshad
rgyan gyi snang ba'i rnam bshad
name: brgyad stong 'grel chen gyi bshad pa

Mentioned by A khu ching Shes rab rgya mtsho, [5RXEUKD9]: 529, No. 11491: jo bos dbus nas 'brom sogs la brgyad stong pa dang rgyan gyi bshad pa mdzad pa la khams pa phyag dar ston pas zin bris.
Notes on the exposition by Atiśa (ID:3745) to 'Brom ston (ID:3827) and others of the Abhisamayālaṃkāra­ (ID:3706) and the  	Aṣṭasāhasrikāprajñāpāramitā (ID:3692).

The work was composed to refute the interpretation of Buddhaśrījñānapāda (ID:6961).

'start': None, 'end': None}]
comments:
Work on the theory of definition composed in thal 'phreng (chains of consequences) style, without citations or references to other works and scholars.

It could correspond to the "tshad ma'i thal phreng mdor bsdus" listed in the Tho yig ([5RXEUKD9]: 675, No. 11849). 

The colophon gives the date of composition as: sa pho spre'u'i la nag pa'i zla ba'i gnam (The year of the male earth monkey, in the waxing moon of the third month. As the author would only have been 7 years old in 1368, 1428 is more likely.
alternative_names: bsdus chos nor bu’i phreng ba
name: bsdus chos nor bu'i phreng ba

An instance of this work is listed in the [8H6M69W4]: No. 19377. In view of the title and number of folios of instance (ID:7051), this work is a topical outline of the Śikṣāsamuccaya (ID:3742).
No author reported for instance (ID:7051) in [8H6M69W4]: 19377. Possibly, the author indicated for No. 19373 is the same for the following items up to No. 19378, i.e., shAkya'i btsun pa smon lam tshul khrims (ID:4052).
name: bslab btus kyi bsdus don

comments:
The existence of a damaged instance of that work in 'Bras spungs gnas bcu lha khang is mentioned in [S635TW6P]: 62. This appears to be the same item as the "bslab pa kun las btus pa'i don cung zad phye ba" reported in [HMSTSJ7Q]: 73, No. 23.1.

In view of the number of folios of (ID:7331) (i.e., 76 fols.), it is probably a commentary rather than just a topical outline, hence a work different from (ID:6554).
alternative_names: bslab pa kun las btus pa'i don cung zad phye ba
name: bslab btus kyi 'grel chen

comments:
Topical outline of Śāntideva’s Śikṣāsamuccaya. It gives a hierarchical structure for the base text (with an initial threefold division), to which it refers by means of interlinear notes indicating lemmas of the base text in the Tibetan translation. Only an incomplete instance is extant (ID:6555). 
The identity of the author as Phya pa (ID:3831) needs to be confirmed, as it could also be Nyang bran Chos kyi seng ge (ID:3884). Both scholars wrote a commentary on the Śikṣāsamuccaya, see work (ID:7053) and work (ID: 6551).
alternative_names: bslab kun btus pa'i bsdus don
name: bslab pa kun las btus pa'i don bsdus pa

comments:
The existence of a manuscript of a memorandum on the explanation of the verses the Śikṣāsamuccaya (ID:3742) is reported in [HMSTSJ7Q]: 73 (bslab pa kun las btus pa'i rtsa ba'i don man ngag gi bshad pa'i brjed byang mang du thos pa'i dge slong brtson 'grus seng ges sbyar ba; 17 fols.).
This may correspond to the commentary on the Śikṣāsamuccaya (ID:3742) by gTsang nag pa listed by A khu ching shes rab rgya mtsho in his Tho yig ([5RXEUKD9]: 514, No. 11065: gtsang nag pa'i bslab btus (dang spyod 'jug gnyis) kyi 'grel pa.
alternative_names: bslab btus kyi 'grel pa
name: bslab pa kun las btus pa'i rtsa ba'i don man ngag gi bshad pa'i brjed byang

comments:
The work contains two parts, entitled respectively "bslab btus kyi bsgom don dpe'i khrid zab po" and "spyod 'jug 'khor lo lta bu'i lam mdor bsdus pa."
According to the post-colophon lineage found in (ID:4840), the work reports a teaching transmitted in a lineage starting with Maitreya, down to sKyo ston (ID:4052), and written down in the course of its transmission to Chos kyi rgyal mtshan (ID:6458).
The colophon of the second part names the author "lha btsun pa," which may refer to sKyo ston.
alternative_names: spyod 'jug 'khor lo lta bu'i lam mdor bsdus pa
name: bslabs btus dang spyod 'jug gi khrid

The work probably corresponds to the "bstan rim rgyas" listed  by A khu ching shes rab rgya mtsho in his Tho yig ([5RXEUKD9]: 515, No. 11108: gro lung pa'i bstan rim rgyas bsdus gnyis).
A complete etext based on the Patna blockprint can be found at: https://asianclassics.org/library/downloads/ > The Sungbum > 27 Lam rim_Steps of the Path > bstan rim chen mo

name: bstan rim chen po

comments:
Only an incomplete manuscript (1 folio) is listed in [8H6M69W4], No. 18819, the contents of which are unknown (ID:6990). See [BAQ9MH4T]: 207, no. 47. 
This "commentary on the teachings of Maitreya" could be identical with one of the commentaries by rNgog Blo ldan shes rab on the Five treatises of Maitreya.
name: byams chos kyi 'grel pa

comments:
The work description in the closing verses (mdo sde kun las btus pa'i don...) and colophon (mdo sde kun las btus pa'i ti ka) indicates a commentary on the Sūtrasamuccaya (ID:3738), but in terms of its contents, the work is a commentary on the Śikṣāsamuccaya (ID:3742). 

According to the colophon, gZhon nu rin chen relies on the explanations of "Chos kyi ye shes" - this is Nyang bran Chos kyi ye shes (ID:3876) in view of the reference to "Nyang gi bran" in the conclusive verses - and that of "brTson 'grus seng ge," likely gTsang nag pa (ID:3839), as the latter was a student of Nyang bran.
The author refers with name to Atiśa ("jo bo chen po", (ID:3745)), Lo tsha ba=rNgog Blo ldan shes rab (ID:3786), and Nyang bran (ID:3876), and refers anonymously to the views of other Tibetan scholars, some of whom (Zhang tshes (ID:3805), Lo tsha ba (ID:3786), sTag lo (ID:7033), Khyung (ID:3809), etc.) are identified in interlinear glosses in instance (ID:4624); the glosses are concentrated in the first 12 folios then resume at two-thirds of the text on after a long break.

The work could correspond to the "bslab btus Tik+ka" listed by A khu ching shes rab rgya mtsho in his Tho yig ([5RXEUKD9]: 514, No. 11073: gzhon nu rin chen gyi bslab btus Tik+ka).
alternative_names:

slab pa kun las btus pa'i ṭikka
byang chub sems dpa'i bslab pa kun las btus pa'i ti ka mdo sde nyi ma'i snying po
mdo sde kun las btus pa'i Ti ka mdo'i nyi ma'i snying po
dge slong gzhon nu rin chen gyis mdzad pa'i bslab pa kun las btus pa'i Tik+ka

comments:
Topical outline of the Bodhicaryāvatāra (ID:3727) similar to but not identical with work (ID:4488).
The "chos kyi seng ge" identified as the author in the colophon of instance (ID:6552) is understood to be Nyang bran in BUDA. This is plausible since Nyang bran is known to have composed a commentary on that text (see work (ID:6550)) and could also have composed a topical outline.
The author could also be Phya pa (ID:3831) - in which case he could be the author of two topical outlines on the Bodhicaryāvatāra (ID:3727).
name: byang chub sems dpa'i spyod 'jug gi bsdus don

It is presumably a topical outline of the Bodhicaryāvatāra (ID:3727).
An instance of this work in 5 folios is preserved at sNye mo Bye mkhar chos sde, see (ID:7059). 
The 7-folio instance entitled "spyod pa la 'jug pa'i don" (ID:7059) could also be an instance of that work ("don" for "bsdus don"?) or an incomplete manuscript of another work on the Bodhicaryāvatāra (ID:3727), see (ID:6860) and (ID:4559).
The 13-folio "spyod 'jug gi sa bcad" ascribed to "brtson 'grus seng ge" (ID:7366) could be an instance of the same work.

gtang nag pa'i spyod 'jug gi bsdus don
name: byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa la 'jug pa'i bsdus don

comments:
Topical outline of the Bodhicaryāvatāra (ID:3727) similar to but not identical with work (ID:7048). It gives a hierarchical structure for the base text (with, initially, a five-fold division), to which it refers by means of interlinear notes indicating lemmas of the base text in the Tibetan translation.
The "chos kyi seng ge" identified as the author in instance (ID:4487) - which follows a topical outline of Śikṣāsamuccaya on the same manuscript, see (ID:6554) - is likely Phya pa (ID:3831). It could also refer to Nyang bran Chos kyi seng ge (ID:3844), which is plausible since the latter is known to have composed a commentary on the Bodhicaryāvatāra as well as on the Śikṣāsamuccaya (see works (ID:6550) and (ID:6551)) and could also have composed topical outlines on these texts.

Date of composition: shing pho 'brugi lo snron gyi zla ba = 1364.

A "spyod 'jug 'grel pa" is  listed by A khu ching shes rab rgya mtsho in his Tho yig ([5RXEUKD9]: 514, No. 11080: rgyal sras thogs med pa'i spyod 'jug 'grel pa legs par bshad pa'i rgya mtsho).

It would correspond to the "spyod 'jug Tik+ka" listed by A khu ching shes rab rgya mtsho in his Tho yig ([5RXEUKD9]: 514, No. 11077: rngog blo ldan shes rab kyi spyod 'jug Tik+ka).

comments:
The incipit indicates that the text is a portion of the "sgrung/sgrungs 'grel" entitled "'bras gsal ba'i me long" (ex28022025-07-1710-30-09).
[8H6M69W4], No. 15574 mistakenly records "'bras gsal ba'i me long zhes bya ba" for the author.
As noted in [Q8WLKLMF]: 25, the ascription of authorship to "dbang phyug rin chen" in the [Z5AUD7GQ] is unfounded. The colophon refers, rather, to a "yon tan dbang phyug" (ID:6857) but it is unclear whether he is the author or the scribe.

The explanation is divided into ten chapters. It is not a standard commentary. Rather, it takes words from the Bodhicaryāvatāra (ID:3727) (ranging from single lines to whole stanzas) and supplies each with a narrative from Indian sources (typically sūtra) intended to illustrate the content.
alternative_names:
dbang phyug rin chen gyis mdzad pa'i byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa la 'jug pa'i sgrung 'grel
byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa la 'jug pa'i sgrungs 'grel
sgrung 'grel ngo mtshar rin chen phreng ba
byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa la 'jug pa'i sgrungs 'gre las 'bras gsal ba'i me long
name: byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa la 'jug pa'i sgrung 'grel

comments:
Commentary in nine chapters combined with a hierarchical structure (sa bcad), with citations from Prajñākaramati's Pañjikā (ID: 6138). 
Chap. 9 contains a long excursus on the Two Truths.

The author refers to the view of several Tibetan scholars, some of whom are identified in instance (ID:4477) in glosses in cursive script (e.g., lo tsa (ID:3786), 'bre (ID:3807), zang kar (ID:3944)) and some by single capital letters (ja, ka, sa, tsa).
alternative_names:
shAkya'i dge slong byang chub grags kyis mdzad pa'i byang chub sems pa la 'jug pa'i tshig don gsal bar bshad pa

byang chub sems dpa’i spyod pa la ’jug pa’i Tik ka
byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa la 'jug pa'i Ti ka
byang chub sems pa'i spyod pa la 'jug pa'i tshig dang don gsal bar bshad pa
rgyal sras spyod pa ’jug pa’i tshigs dang don legs bshad
rgyal sras spyod pa ’jug pa’i tshigs dang don gsal bar bshad pa
byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa la 'jug pa'i Tik+ka

comments:
Commentary on the Śikṣāsamuccaya (ID:3742). The author also wrote a topical outline of that work, see (ID:4647).

The author refers to the views of his predecessors, some of whom are identified in glosses in (ID:4648), for instance lo tsa ba (ID:3786), Phya pa (ID:3831), Zhang tshes (ID:3805).

The discussion on "dgos 'brel" bears a close similarity to that found in the works of Phya pa, speaking in favor of the author being his student 'Jad pa Byang chub skyabs.

comments:
Commentary in the form of "chos can...te...phyir" arguments.
The text has chapter divisions but no nested hierarchical structure (sa bcad). 
The author claims to follow the teaching of his teacher, mChims Blo bzang grags pa (ID:4007), author of a commentary with a similar title (ID:5279).

comments:
Topical outline, without references to the base text, which could be the Abhidharmasamuccaya (ID:3755).
Author according to [8H6M69W4], No. 19864: slob dpon dbyig gnyen, maybe on account of the post-colophon note in (ID:5307): 'phags pa 'jam dpa la phyag tshal lo || slob dpon dbyig nyen (sic) kyis mdzad pa'i phung po lnga pa'i rab du dbye' ba ...
name: chos mngon pa'i bsdus don

comments:
Commentary in the form of thal-phyir arguments.
It corresponds to the work listed in A khu ching Shes rab rgya mtsho's Tho yig ([5RXEUKD9]: 532, No. 11687: [zhwa lu rin chen bsod nams 'phel gyi] mdzod kyi sbyor Tik mkhas pa'i yid 'phrog).
Date of composition: chu mo glang gi zla ba dang po'i tshes brgyad (in the year of the female water ox, on the eighth day of the first Tibetan month).
alternative_names:
mdzod kyi sbyor Tik mkhas pa'i yid 'phrog
mngon mdzod kyi sbyor ba'i Ti ka mkhas pa'i yid 'phrog
dam pa'i chos mngon pa mdzod kyi sbyor ba'i TI ka mkhas pa'i yid 'phrog
name: chos mngon pa'i mdzod kyi sbyor ba'i Ti ka mkhas pa'i yid 'phrog

comments: The main text in the two instances features numerous differences. The edited text in (ID:7003) contains what appears to have been glosses on the source, which are inserted in the main text in parentheses. The same additions appear as glosses on a block-print of the text (ID:7013). These glosses do not correspond to the glosses on instances (ID:5274) and (ID:5276).

a b+hi d+harmA koSHa kUsi ka bri ti a b+hi a laM ka ra

comments:
An instance of this work is listed in [8H6M69W4]: No. 16078. In view its title and the number of folios of instance (ID:6992), it is a topical outline or a concise guide on the Abhidharmakośa (ID:3761).
The identity of the author is uncertain and it is not clear whether the same "Rin chen tshul khrims" was the author of this work and of work (ID:5271).

comments:
Date of composition: shing pho spre'u'i chu stod gyi zla ba'i tshe 1 (The wood male monkey year of the first day of the month of Āṣāḍha). This could be 1344 or 1404. The former date would not allow the identification of the author's teacher named in the colophon (ID:4131) as the third abbot of gSer ri dgon.

The ornamental title "slob ma la phan pa" echoes that of work (ID:5482).
alternative_names:
chos mngon pa mdzod kyi rnam bshad slob ma la phan pa zhes bya ba'i 'grel pa
chos mngon mdzod kyi rnam bshad pa slob ma la phan pa
name: chos mngon pa mdzod kyi rnam bshad slob ma la phan pa

'ex1062023-05-24.16.57', 'support_notes': 'The text is ascribed to Blo ldan shes rab (ID: 3786) by dNgos grub rgya mtsho (ca. 1580) and A kya Yongs ’dzin Blo bzang don grub (ca. 1760–1830) alias dByangs can dga’ ba’i blo gros. But van der Kuijp contests this authorship based on the spelling of some words in the manuscript and the occurrence of the expression hor ’dra, the first use of which he situates around 1240–1350 (<<van der Kuijp 2003 [FZ6N88AU]>>: 392, referred to in [KHA9ZVGP]: 18, n. 55).', 'confidence': 'Uncertain', 'start': None, 'end': None}]
comments:
Explanation in 7-syllable verses and a few passages in prose at the beginning of each of the five sections announced in the programmatic verse:  the numerical determination of graphs and ligatures, the particles, what is to be accepted or rejected about prefixes and postscripts, and various classifications of additional matter (see [UBZQCTMF]: 436).
The author refers to three unidentified "kha cig," whose views are refuted.
alternative_names:

dag yig nyer mkho bsdus pa
dag yig nye mkho bsdus pa
name: dag yig nyer mkho bsdus pa

comments:
This work is listed in A khu ching Shes rab rgya mtsho's Tho yig ([5RXEUKD9]: 532, no. 11687: [zhwa lu rin chen bsod nams 'phel gyi] mdzod kyi dka' 'grel mkhas pa'i yid 'phrog).

Date of composition indicated in the colophon in (ID:5498), fol. 175b6-7: dkar rtsid pa'i lugs kyi ¦ thun mong gi lo ¦ nag rtsis pa'i lugs kyi ¦ lung pho khyi'i lo ¦ ston zla 'bring po tha skar zla ba'i chos lnga. This corresponds to 1430.

comments:
The title "sdom pa dam tshig mdor bsdus pa" is reported in [2PUVZG5F]: 46.
A post-colophon addition in (ID:5334) reports that the teaching of that text was requested by "rngos" (whom a gloss in dbu can identifies as "mar ston") from "lca/lba ston jo dga'" (lca/lba ston jo dga' la rngos ‹mar ston› kyis mnyan zhus nan tan bgyis so). Dan Martin (who reads "lba ston") notes "There was a Jo-dga' in the western Tibetan royal lineage whose lifespan could have coincided with Rinchen Zangpo's (Roerich’s Blue Annals, p. 38)" ([F8AC4NRI]). See [R894SIKE]: 63 for the reference to "jo dga'".

comments:
Topical outline of the Satyadvayavibhaṅga (ID:3729). 
In instance (ID:4479), references to lemmata of the base text are found in interlinear notes. 
This topical outline proposes a hierarchical structure of the base text similar to the one adopted by the author in his commentary on the same text (ID: 5874). See [J8TZBG2Q].

comments:
This seems to correspond to the dBu ma bden gnyis kyi 'grel pa listed by A khu ching shes rab rgya mtsho in his Tho yig ([5RXEUKD9]: 522, No. 11317: phya pa chos seng gi dbu ma bden gnyis [...] kyi Tik ka).
The lemmata from the source text sometimes represent a Tibetan translation different from the canonical one.
alternative_names:

dbu ma bden pa gnyis rnam par bshad pa yi ge nyung ngus gzhung gsal bar byed pa
dbu ma bden gnyis kyi Tik ka
name: dbu ma bden gnyis kyi rnam bshad

comments:
Independent composition on Madhyamaka articulated around the presentation of the Two Truths according to a structure common to other authors such as rGya dmar ba, Gro lung pa, etc. The author support the Svātantrika orientation and criticizes followers of Candrakīrti. Its composition predates the author's commentary on the Madhyamakāloka (ID:4484), which mentions its title.

This text could corresponds to either the short or large "bsdus pa" listed A khu ching shes rab rgya mtsho in his Tho yig ([5RXEUKD9]: 523, No. 11321: [phya pa chos seng gi...] dbu ma'i bsdus pa che chung gnyis). The other work is not extant (ID:6568).

Detailed table of contents in [KYDHTU7S].
alternative_names:
dbu ma'i de kho na nyid bsdus pa
dbu ma shar gsum gyi stong thun
dge slong phywa pa chos kyi seng ges mdzad pa'i dbu ma'i de kho na nyid bsdus pa
dbu ma'i bsdus pa che
name: dbu ma de kho na nyid kyi snying po

comments:
This work is not extant. 
It was available in the 15th century, as 'Gos lo tsA ba gzhon nu dpal (ID:5839) reports he had seen it ([R894SIKE]: 407).
It is listed in A khu ching Shes rab rgya mtsho's Tho yig ([5RXEUKD9]: 523, No. 11348: par phu ba'i dbu ma'i rtsa Tik).
name: dbu ma'i rtsa Tik

comments:
Corresponds to the "Tik+ka" listed A khu ching shes rab rgya mtsho in his Tho yig ([5RXEUKD9]: 523, No. 11319: [phya pa chos seng gi...] dbu ma rgyan [gsum] gyi Tik ka).

Commentary on Śāntarakṣita’s Madhyamakālaṃkāravṛtti (ID:3733), with some references to a “commentator” (ti ka byed) and to numerous anonymous opponents. Like in the commentary on the Satyadvayavibhaṅga (see (ID:5874)), the author uses a
question-and-answer style to explain the words of the text. A few lemmas hint to a different translation of the base text. In particular, the verse MA 1 is cited in a version different from the canonical one.

Edition and translation of some portions of the work in [WLWGS439]: appendix and footnotes.
alternative_names:
phywa pa chos seng ges mdzad pa'i dbu ma rgyan gyi 'grel ba
dbu ma rgyan gyi 'grel pa
dbu ma rgyan gyi ‘grel pa rgya cher bshad pa rigs par smra ba'i dge slong chos kyi seng ges sbyar ba
name: dbu ma rgyan gyi 'grel pa rgya cher bshad pa

This work might correspond to the "dbu ma'i bsdus pa" (ID:6574) or the "dbu ma'i stong thun (ID:6573) listed in A khu ching shes rab rgya mtsho's Tho yig ([5RXEUKD9]: 523, No. 11324 and No. 11325).

comments:
Divided in 27 chapter, combined with a nested hierarchical structure (sa bcad).
On (ID:4666), fol. 8b, explanation of the syllables of the Sanskrit word "pratītyasamutpāda."

The work was composed in Thang po che (ID:5660) and hence must post-date 1017, the date the monastery was founded.

comments:
Date of composition: dbang phyug gi lo smin drug can gyi zla ba'i dkar phyogs kyi tshes cu gsum (1397?).
It is yet to be determined whether this is a commentary  on the Mūla­madhyamaka­kārikā following the commentary of Candrakīrti, or a commentary on the Prasannapadā (ID:3724).
The colophon names a number of persons having requested the teaching, none of which has been identified so far.

name: dbu ma rtsa ba shes rab kyi 'grel pa tshig don rab gsal

comments:
Corresponds to the "Tik+ka" listed A khu ching shes rab rgya mtsho in his Tho yig ([5RXEUKD9]: 522, No. 11318: [phya pa chos seng gi ...] dbu ma snang ba [...gsum] gyi Tik ka).

Commentary on Kamalaśīla's Madhyamakāloka (ID:3734) post-dating Phya pa's dBu ma snying po (ID:4486) as it mentions the latter's title as "'jug ngogs bsdu ba."
alternative_names:
phywa pa chos seng ges mdzad pa'i dbu ma snang ba'i 'grel pa
dbu ma'i yig cha phya pas byas pa
dbu ma snang ba'i gzhung gi don rigs pa'i tshul dang myi 'gal zhing blo chung bas kyang bde blag du rtogs pa byis pa'i 'jug ngos (sic) su sbyar ba
dbu ma snang ba'i gzhung gi don rigs pa'i tshul dang myi 'gal zhing blo chung bas kyang bde blag du rtogs pa byis pa'i 'jug ngogs su sbyar ba
name: dbu ma snang ba'i 'grel pa

comments:
Listed as part of rNgog Blo ldan shes rab's compositions by several Tibetan scholars, along with a "don bsdus," which is extant (ID:4439) (see <<Kano 2016 [BAQ9MH4T]>>: 203–204). 
See also A khu ching Shes rab rgya mtsho's Tho yig ([5RXEUKD9]: 528, no. 11472: byams chos gzhan bzhi'i rnam bshad).
alternative_names: dbus dang mtha’ rnam ’byed rnam bshad
name: dbus dang mtha' rnam 'byed kyi rnam bshad

comments:
Concise guide to the Madhyāntavibhāga (ID:3748) with references to Sthiramati's ṭīkā/bhāṣya (ID: 6261) and Vasubandhu's tīkā (ID: 5585). The author also compares both commentaries on specific points, but does not discuss other Tibetan interpretations.
This work probably corresponds to the "don bdus" listed by several Tibetan scholars (see <<Kano 2016 [BAQ9MH4T]>>: 202-203). A "rnam bshad" is also listed, which is not extant (ID: 6054).
alternative_names:
dbus dang mtha' rnam 'byed kyi don bsdus
dbus dang mtha' rnam 'byed don bsdus
dbus mtha'i don bsdu
dbus dang mtha' rnam par 'byed pa'i don bsdus pa
name: dbus mtha'i don bsdus

comments:
Listed as part of rNgog blo ldan shes rab's compositions by several Tibetan scholars, along with a "de kho na la 'jug pa'i gzhung bsdus pa" (ID:6076) (see <<Kano 2016 [BAQ9MH4T]>>: 204).

Possibly related to the the Tattvāvatāravṛtti (ID:6683) of Śrīgupta (see <<Kramer 2007 [Q47PVAE6]>>: 111, n. 174).
name: de kho na la 'jug pa'i don bsdus pa

'start_date_from': None, 'start_date_sort': None, 'zotero_refs': '[DEUJAY2D]: 78-80.', 'tei_refs': 'ex019032025-11-1014-03-33', 'support_notes': 'The closing verse contains the hidden signature "byang chub grags," like in rGya dmar ba\'s dBu ma\'i de kho na nyid gtan la dbab pa (ID:4686). It imitates the closing verse of the Satyadvayavibhaṅgavṛtti (ID:3729) that has the hidden signature "ye shes snying po"=Jñānagarbha (ID:3730).', 'confidence': 'Positive', 'start': None, 'end': None}]
comments:
Commentary on Satyadvayavibhaṅgavṛtti (ID:3729) including many references to Śāntarakṣita’s Satyadvayavibhaṅgapañjikā (ID: 6193). 
This work may correspond to the text listed by A khu ching shes rab rgya mtsho in the Tho yig ([5RXEUKD9]: 523, No. 11347: stod lung gad sa rgya dmar pa byang chub grags pa'i dbu ma bden gnyis kyi Tik+ka) ([DEUJAY2D]: 79 and 84, n. 8).

It is likely that the "commentary on the [Atiśa's] Satyadvaya" reported in [CCSBSVCA]: 420, n. 25 is this work. 
[S635TW6P]: 86 also describes instance (ID:4598) it as a commentary on Atiśa's commentary on the two truths (ID:6040), but it is clear from the contents that it comments on (ID:3729).

Colophon: ex019032025-11-1013-30-57

dbu ma'i rnam bshad
dbu ma'i rnam bshad bzhugs pa lags so
name: de kho na nyid don gsal bar byed pa

comments: Versified eulogy praising the 62-deity maṇḍala transmitted in the Lūyīpāda tradition of Cakrasaṃvara (see <<Kawasaki 2007 [X22QU3VM]>>: 212). 16 verses of 4 lines of 7 syllables (v. 1, 7–16) and 9 syllables (v. 2–6), all expressing an invocation (… phyag ’tshal lo).

comments: Short work on Indian contributions to epistemology and logic (tshad ma), with a section on non-Buddhist representatives and a section on Buddhist representatives and their works. The former mentions the four Vedas (citing PV (ID:3772) 1.239 and Tarkajvālā (ID:5586)), the treatises of the proponents of cessation (chad par smar ba) (referring to "Avalokitavrata's Prajñā­pradīpa­ṭīkā (ID:7344)), and the proponents of eternalism (rtag par smra ba). Buddhist epistemology is said to have been prophethized by Buddha Kāśyapa. The author contests the idea that the lineage starts with *Dharmatrāta and Vasubandhu (ID:3758), naming instead the Vādavidhi ascribed to Vasubandhu as the only work prior to the works of Dignāga (ID:3771). He is also critical of the conformity of the works of Prajñākaragupta (ID:5557) and Śaṅkaranandana (ID:5552) with the intention of Dharmakīrti (ID:3773) and Dignāga.
alternative_names:
rtog ge tshad ma phyi nang gsum la sogs pa'i byung tshul lung rig bstan pa'i bdag po bcom ldan ral gris mdzad pa sogs ngo mtshar che'o
phyi nang gi rtog ge tshad ma'i bstan bcos ji ltar byung ba'i tshul 
tshad ma'i byung tshul lo rgyus

comments: Mentioned by dPal mang dKon mchog rgyal mtshan in the following passage: "rngog gi bstan bcos gze ma ra mgo zhes pa las | lam ’bras rdo rje tshig rkang la dgag pa yod par grags pa la |" (see [Q47PVAE6]: 242, n. 53,  <<Kano 2016 [BAQ9MH4T]>>: 207, n. 75). Kramer and Kano take "rNgog" to be rNgog Blo ldan shes rab (ID: 3786), which is doubtful. The content is about lam 'bras teaching, for which another branch of the rNgog family led by Chos sku rdo rje (ID: 6115) is famous.
name: gze ma ra mgo

comments:
The work was committed to writing in rTse dkar (ID:5574), see (ID:5867). Two manuscripts are extant, with slightly different readings in several places; see (ID:5593) and (ID:4770).

The author refers in this work to the views of rNgog Blo ldan shes rab (ID:3786) - citing his "tik chung" (ID:4445) -, Khyung Rin chen grags (ID:3809), Phya pa (ID:3831), gTsang nag pa (ID:3839), and gNyal zhig (ID:3887), and refers as well to his own teacher (bdag gyi yongs su 'dzin pa) and to anonymous scholars (kha cig), including supporters of the "summaries" (bsdus pa smra ba, bsdus pa smra ba la mkhas par grags pa). In (ID:5593) a "gcung lo tsa ba" is also mentioned in a passage absent in (ID:4770).
alternative_names:

rigs pa'i de nyid gsal ba

name: gzhan gyi phyogs thams cad las rnam par rgyal ba

comments: This appears to be a commentary on an unidentified work of epistemology-cum-madhyamaka, parts of which are cited in the text. The author supports the view of the prāsaṅgika orientation and of the "great Madhyamaka" (dbu ma chen po). The text covers basic notions such as the types of valid cognition, the theory of definition, the two truths. Arguments are frequently presented in the chos can-te-phyir and chos can-thal-phyir format. It includes numerous citations of Indian works.
name: gzhi lam 'bras gsum gyi don rgyas tshig 'dus kyi rtsa ba

comments: Instance (ID:5068) contains several eulogies/prayers, (i) f. 1b-2a7 "'jam pa'i dbyangs la bston pa", requested by yang dag pa'i dge ba'i bshes gnyen dpal ldan ye shes, composed by btsun pa thogs med. (ii) 2a7-3b3 "'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug la bston pa'i tshigs su bcad pa phan bde'i 'byung gnas", composed by ma Ni pa thogs med in dNgul chu'i chos rdzong. (iii) 3b3-5a4 "spyan ras gzigs la bstod pa tshig rgyan me tog phreng ba", composed by chos smra ba'i btun pa thog pa med; (iv) 5a4-6a3 ?; (v) 6a3-7a1 "bsnyen rdzogs kyi mkhan rgyud la bston pa", requested by slob dpon byams chos pa byang chub rgyal mtshan, composed by chos smra ba'i btun pa thogs med in dNgul chu'i chos rdzong, scribe was 'byam (sic) dbyangs dkar po ; (vi) 7a1-7b8, composed by thogs med for the "jo bo bskor ba rnams".
name: jo bo rin po che'i bstod pa la sogs pa yi dam gyi lha 'ga' zhig gi bstod pa

comments:
The central part of the work deals with 14 topics, divided into two pairs ('gal/'brel, dgag/sgrub, spyi/bye brag, mtshan nyid/mtshon bya, khyab bya/khyab byed, gcig/tha dad, rdzas/ldog). These are reminding of the "lessons" in bsdus grwa compositions, and resemble Tsong kha pa's (ID:5636) Don gnyer mun sel. Pairs of topics are also used to structure the presentation in work (ID:4767) by Byang chub sems dpa' dz+nya na shrI (ID:4017) and work (ID:4773) by Sangs rgyas rgyal mtshan (ID:5910) (See [J4L5X9AG]: 435-436)
The author adopts the fourfold typology of object (snang yul, gzung yul, zhen yul, 'jug yul).
The style makes abundant use of chains of consequences (thal 'phreng) also involving the pronoun "khyod."
Date of composition: sbrang rtsi 'dzin pa'i dkar phyogs (the waxing moon of the summer months, i.e., April-June). The work post-dates 1219 as it refers to the views of upholders of the Tshad ma rigs gter (ID:5564). (See (ID:4780), fol. 10a9, 16a9, 23b8).
alternative_names:
rigs pa dang mi rigs pa'i de kho na nyid rnam par 'byed pa legs par bshad pa'i gter mdzod blo gsal gyi yid la dga' ba gter ba
legs par bshad pa'i gter mdzod blo gsal yid la dga' ba ster byed
legs par bshad pa'i gter mdzod blo gsal yid la dga' ba ster ba
name: legs par bshad pa'i gter mdzod blo gsal yid la dga' ba gter ba

comments: Work on ritual and meditation relating to the bKa' gdams pa, claiming to be derived from earlier sources. It mentions the names of central figures of the early bKa' gdams tradition. The work deals with the bKa' gdams thig le bcu drug, although it does not refer to this text by name.
name: lha chos nyams len gyi man ngag thig le chen po'i dbyings su byang chub kyi sems spel ba

comments:
See [BAQ9MH4T]: 406 and [NCQ5GCTN]. Small work in 37 verses. It is extant as a single folio palm-leaf manuscript in Proto-Sarada script written by a Kashmiri scribe. Previously preserved at Zhwa lu ri phug monastery, it is now likely housed in the Tibet Museum in Lhasa. The manuscript contains interlinear notes by an anonymous hand.
[NCQ5GCTN] contains a structural analysis and a synoptic analysis, as well as a translation and reading text.
name: mahāyānottaratantraśāstropadeśa

comments:
Commentary on the Pramāṇaviniścaya (ID:3774) addressing about fourteen points (with mention of words from the corresponding passage of the Pramāṇaviniścaya) in the form of chains of arguments by consequence, with abundant use of the pronoun “khyod.” 

[8H6M69W4] does not mention an author for instance (ID:4778), but the previous two works, which have the same folio size and script, as well as the same double numbering of the folios, are by Zwha lu rin chen bsod nams 'phel (ID:4129). The authorship is likely the same for this work, which adopts a similar style of presentation as other works by Zhwa lu rin chen bsod nams, several of which have the expression "phreng" in their title.

This work could correspond to the items No. 11847-11848 listed by A khu shes rab rgya mtsho in the Tho yig ([5RXEUKD9]: 675, No. 11847: zhwa lu rin chen bsod nams 'phel gyi rnam nges sbyor Tik gzhan phan nor phreng le'u gnyis pa yan, and No. 11848: gzhan don le'u'i rnam bzhag). 
It could also correspond to No. 11849: tshad ma'i thal phreng mdor bsdus (or this item could correspond to (ID:5306)).

The work is mistakenly ascribed to bSam gtan bzang po (ID:4005) in the [UJDXNMGD] due to a fragment of the latter's epistemological commentary (see work (ID:6010)) being copied at the end of the work in instance (ID:4778).
alternative_names: thal phreng mdor bsdus pa
name: mdor bsdus thal 'gyur phreng ba

Chos kyi seng ge.', 'support_notes': '', 'confidence': 'Uncertain', 'start': None, 'end': None}]
comments:
The author systematically juxtaposes the interpretations of the base text by Sajjana (ID:3800) and Parahitabhadra (ID:3798) and mentions also rNgog Blo ldan shes rab (ID:3786), his own bla ma, and once bTsan (ID:4141) and an unidentified "kha" (maybe the same person).
A post-colophon note in instance (ID:4493) describes the text as a record (zin bris) of the explanations on Vasubandu’s Mahāyānasūtrālaṅkārabhāṣya, Asvabhāva’s Mahāyānasūtrālaṃkāraṭīkā, Jñānaśrī’s
Sutrālaṅkārapiṇḍārtha, Parahitabhadra, Sajjana, btsan (ID:4141), tsang nag and ar (ID:3816).

This work - or (ID:4497) - might correspond to one of the commentaries listed in A khu ching Shes rab rgya mtsho's Tho yig ([5RXEUKD9]: 528, No. 11474: [phya pa chos seng gi] byams chos phyi ma bzhi'i 'grel ba).

comments:
This work is a concise guide on the Mahāyānasūtrālaṅkāra (ID:3746) (ascribed by the author to Maitreya in the conclusive verses), with references to Vasubandhu’s Vyākhya/Bhāṣya (ID:5571). The Tibetan version of these source-texts, the first of which is the most frequently cited, sometimes differs from the canonical translation. Both texts in the canon were translated by Śākyasiṃha and Bande dpal brtsegs; the first was revised by rNgog Blo ldan shes rab, together with Parahitabhadra and Sajjana. The differences pertaining the Vyākhya might represent a revision of its translation by rNgog Blo ldan shes rab that did not find its way into the canon.
This work probably corresponds to the "don bdus" listed by several Tibetan scholars (see <<Kano 2016 [BAQ9MH4T]>>: 203). A "rnam bshad" is also listed, which is not extant (ID: 6052).

mdo sde rgyan gyi don bsdus
name: mdo sde rgyan gyi don bsdus

comments:
Summary of rNgog Blo ldan shes rab's mDo sde rgyan gyi don bsdus (ID:4437) based on a 58-folio manuscript from Chos sdings (ID:6258) (See annotation: shog gu nga brgyad chos sding gi phyag dpe nas btus so). 
It is unclear whether this summary is by the compiler, Tho yon ye shes don grub bstan pa'i rgyal mtshan (1792-1855), or an earlier scholar. See <<van der Kuijp 1987 [7FZ3B926]>>: 126, n. 12, <<Kramer 2007 [Q47PVAE6]>>: 110, n. 168.
name: mdo sde rgyan gyi don bsdus las btus pa

comments: Rin chen bzang po is reporting the teaching of Atiśa (ID:3745) on the Śrī-(Cakrasaṃvara-)Abhisamaya. The text refers to the words of the Cakrasaṃvara-Abhisamaya. The explanations find parallels in Atiśa’s Abhisamayavibhaṅga (ID: 6213) (see <<Kano and Kawasaki 2014 [IWEZ79V4]>> for cross-references).

comments:
Commentary on the first chapter of the Pramāṇaviniścaya (ID:3774), on perception.
The title echoes the ornamental title "mkhas pa'i yid 'phrog" of three works by Zha lu pa Rin chen bsod nams 'phel ba (ID:4129), see (ID:5497), (ID:5499) and (ID:6872).
name: mngon sum le'u'i 'grel pa slob ma'i yid 'phrog

comments:
The work was composed in the year "me mo lugs gi lo smin drug zla ba'i dkar phyogs" - {Kārttika śukla pakṣa} = 1127, 1187, 1247, 1307, 1367... - when the author (ID:4674) was 80 years old.
The work is generally practice/meditation orientated and discusses the correct understanding of Mahāmudrā. Also mentioned are the arising of the "thal 'gyur pa"  in Tibet following Pa tshab (ID:3868)'s return (before which, according to the author, only the "rang rgyud pa" was attested in Tibet), and the ulterior emergence of the rang stong/gzhan stong distinction ((ID:5130), fol. 18.1b4-5).
name: mtha' bral dbu ma'i rnam bzhag gsal byed sgron me

comments:
The authorship of the work comes to be ascribed to the future Buddha Maitreya (ID:3747) in the Indian tradition from the 11th c. onward and in the Tibetan tradition. On earlier witnesses ascribing the authorship to Sāramati or Sthiramati, see [BAQ9MH4T]: 20-27. No attribution of that work to Asaṅga (ID:3756) was located in Indian sources, but the colophon of the Tibetan translation by rNgog Blo ldan shes rab ascribes the verses to Maitreya and the prose commentary to Asaṅga ([BAQ9MH4T]: 27-28).
There are six Tibetan translations, only that by rNgog Blo ldan shes rab and Sajjana is currently extant ([BAQ9MH4T]: chap. 6).
alternative_names:
rātnagotravibhāga mahāyānottaratantraśāstra
uttaratantra
theg pa chen po rgyud bla ma'i bstan bcos
name: ratnagotravibhāga

comments:
Commentary on the Ratnagotravibhāga (ID:3749).
The author also composed a "bsdus don" on that work (ID:7105).
The "rgyud bla ma'i 'grel ba" seems to correspond to the "rgyud bla ma'i Tik+ka" listed in A khu ching Shes rab rgya mtsho's Tho yig ([5RXEUKD9]: 523, No. 11337: karma dkon mchog gzhon nu [rnams] kyis mdzad pa'i rgyud bla ma'i Tik+ka).

According to the colophon, the work was started on the third day of the waxing phase of the moon in the fourth month and ended on the 1st day of the waning phase in the fifth month, in the "drag po" year, the 54th year of the cycle, which could correspond to 1320 or 1380, probably the latter.

The work is also part of the author's gSung 'bum published in 2021 ([CDT96KV7], vol. 1).

Colophon: (ID:6585), fol. 87a3-4: kar ma dkon mchog gzhon nus dben gnas chen po sa bzang du drag po'i lo'i sa ga'i zla ba'i  dkar phyogs kyi tshes gsum las dbu btsugs te | snron gyi zla ba'i nag phyogs kyi tshes [gcig] la legs par grub pa'o || bstan pa rin po che dang sems can dpag tu med pa la phan pa rgya chen po 'byung bar gyur cig |
alternative_names: rgyud bla ma'i Tik+ka
name: rgyud bla ma'i 'grel pa rton pa bzhi ldan mkhas pa dga' byed

comments:
Listed as part of rNgog Blo ldan shes rab's compositions by several Tibetan scholars, along with a "don bsdus" on the same base text (see <<Kano 2016 [BAQ9MH4T]>>: 203). It is unclear whether these two refer to a larger and a smaller commentary, or to a commentary and a topical outline. We assume here, following [BAQ9MH4T]: 203, that the one called "don bsdus/don bsdus" in these lists corresponds to a concise guide entitled "don bsdus pa" that is extant (ID:4441), and that the one called "rnam bshad" is a larger commentary that is not extant. It could however be the case that "rnam bshad" refers to the extant concise guide, and "bsdus don" to the extant topical outline (ID:6106).

See also A khu ching Shes rab rgya mtsho's Tho yig ([5RXEUKD9]: 528, No. 11472: byams chos gzhan bzhi'i rnam bshad).
alternative_names: rgyud bla ma rnam bshad
name: rgyud bla ma'i rnam bshad

comments:
This commentary on the Ratnagotravibhāga (ID:3749) consisting in a record taken during Sajjana's (ID:3800) teaching to the author is mentioned in [R894SIKE]: 423 (de dus su gzus zin bris byas pa'i rgyud bla ma la yig cha yang yod par 'dug) and listed in A khu ching Shes rab rgya mtsho's Tho yig ([5RXEUKD9]: 523, No. 11338: paN+Dita sadz+jana'i gsung la lo tsA ba gzu dga' rdor gyis zin bris byas pa'i rgyud bla ma'i rnam bshad). 

Kano notes that the interlinear notes on the Sanskrit manuscript of Sajjana's Mahāyānottaratantraśāstropadeśa (ID:6588) could constitute gZu's memoranda ([BAQ9MH4T]: 406, n. 5).
alternative_names:

paṇḍita sadzjana'i gsung la lo tsā ba gzu dga' rdor gyis zin bris byas ba'i rgyud bla ma'i rnam bshad
name: rgyud bla ma'i rnam bshad

comments:
A commentary by "Nyang bran" is mentioned by 'Gos lo tsA ba (ID:5839) and listed in A khu ching Shes rab rgya mtsho's Tho yig ([5RXEUKD9]: 523, No. 11334: de'i slob ma nyang brang pa chos kyi ye shes [...] mdzad pa'i rgyud bla ma'i Tik+ka). See Kano [BAQ9MH4T]: 408.

According to 'Gos lo tsA ba, this commentary was based on the commentaries of Gro lung pa (see (ID:6579)) and Zhang tshes spong (see (ID:6580)), themselves based on the small commentary by rNgog Blo ldan shes rab (ID:4441). See [7V8MZYAI]: 4 (rngog gis rgyud bla ma'i 'grel pa la TI kA chung yang mdzad cing | de la brten nas gro lung pa dang | zhang tshes kyis kyang TI kA mdzad de | de gnyis la brten nas nyang bran gyis kyang TI kA mdzad la |).
name: rgyud bla ma'i Tik+ka

comments:
The work is a compilation of definitions and typologies organized in 20 topics (which reminds one of the "lessons" in bsdus grwa compositions), which are the same as in work (ID:4773) by Sangs rgyas rgyal mtshan (ID:5910). See [J4L5X9AG]: 435.
Date of composition: drag po'i lo sa ga zla ba'i dkar phyogs. The waxing phase of the moon, in the "drag po" year: this indicates the 54th year of the cycle, which could correspond to 1260 - at the earliest, since the work cites the Tshad ma rigs gter (ID:5564) - 1320, or 1380 (probably not later).

comments:
According to the colophon, this work is based on the teachings of Red mda' ba (ID: 6756), Tsong kha pa (ID: 5636), Kun dga' dpal (ID: 7075), and their disciples.

A 63-folio dbu can manuscript is preserved at Se ra. See [HMSTSJ7Q]: 387 (gDan sa chen po se ra theg chen gling gi tshogs chen yang thog gzims chung du bzhugs su gsol ba'i dpe rnying dkar chag), No. 1994: ga 26; tshad ma rigs thigs kyi 'grel ba legs bshad snying po'i gter; rgyal tshab dar ma rin chen; dbu can; 63 fols.; 59 x 10 cm.

rig thigs rnam bshad

comments: A Tibetan indigenous commentary on the Nyāyabindu. The first chapter (pratyakṣa) is preserved in Tangut translation. The Tibetan title can be reconstructed as *Rigs pa’i thigs pa’i tshig don gsal bar byed pa on the basis of the Tangut rendering (tśhja wo gjiwr ˑjij gjwi wo dźju sji). See [3HXACZSD]: chap. 5.
alternative_names: tśhja wo gjiwr ˑjij gjwi wo dźju sji
name: rigs pa’i thigs pa’i tshig don gsal bar byed pa

comments:
This work is a concise guide to Dharmottara's Nyāyabinduṭīkā (ID:3779), and not to the Pramāṇaviniścaya, as the [S635TW6P] title (tshad ma rnam nges kyi bsdus don) suggests. The colophons identifies it as an "explanation of the five 'bam po'." "The Five bam po" is a nickname for the Nyāyabinduṭīkā based on its length as reported in the lHan dkar catalogue ([WAHGRFDB]: 336).
See [GHC9CLWS] for an introduction.

This work probably corresponds to the "bsdus don" listed by several Tibetan scholars (see <<Kano 2016 [BAQ9MH4T]>>: 205). A "rnam bshad" is also listed, which is not extant (ID: 6083).

The author cites the Pramāṇasamuccaya (ID:3770), the Pramāṇavārttika (ID:3772), the Pramāṇaviniścaya (ID:3774) and Pramāṇaviniścayaṭīkā (ID:5594). He further refers four times to the views of other scholars without giving their name.
alternative_names:
tshad ma rnam nges kyi bsdus don (sic)
mtshan nyid kyi chos
bam po lnga pa'i bshad pa
rigs thigs 'grel don bsdus
rigs thigs 'grel pa dang bcas pa'i bsdus don
name: rigs thigs 'grel pa'i don bsdus

relations: [{'id': 5059, 'label': "rma bya byang chub brtson 'grus (3842) author of rtog ge la 'jug pa gsal bar byed pa'i rgyan (7164)", 'subj': {'url': 'https://tibschol.acdh-ch-dev.oeaw.ac.at/apis/api/apis_ontology.person/3842/', 'label': "rma bya byang chub brtson 'grus (3842)", 'content_type_key': 'apis_ontology.person', 'content_type_name': 'person'}, 'obj': {'url': 'https://tibschol.acdh-ch-dev.oeaw.ac.at/apis/api/apis_ontology.work/7164/', 'label': "rtog ge la 'jug pa gsal bar byed pa'i rgyan (7164)", 'content_type_key': 'apis_ontology.work', 'content_type_name': 'work'}, 'end_date_to': None, 'end_date_from': None, 'end_date_sort': None, 'start_date_to': None, 'start_date_from': None, 'start_date_sort': None, 'zotero_refs': '[2U5M75NJ]: 11–18.', 'tei_refs': '', 'support_notes': '', 'confidence': 'Positive', 'start': 'after 1100', 'end': 'after 1100'}]
comments:
A summary of Buddhist epistemology by rMa bya Byang chub brtson 'grus (see [2U5M75NJ]: 11–18), lost in Tibetan but partially preserved in Tangut translation. The Tibetan title can be reconstructed as *rTog ge la 'jug pa gsal bar byed pa'i rgyan. 

The work was translated in Mt. Mati, which was located in the Tangut State. The fact that the translation was done by rMa bya and a Tangut scholar (much like how Tibetan translations of Sanskrit works were done by an Indian paṇḍita and a Tibetan lo tsā ba) indicates it was translated before rMa bya's death in 1185. 

For more details, see [2U5M75NJ].
alternative_names: sew ˑjij ˑo śjij dźju sji lju̱ tshjịj
name: rtog ge la 'jug pa gsal bar byed pa'i rgyan

comments:
Summary of epistemology with a nested hierarchical structure combined with a threefold chapter division.
The author follows the system of Phya pa (ID:3831) on key points such as the sevenfold typology of mind, the threefold typology of objects, etc.. 
He frequently refers anonymously to the views of other Tibetan scholars, who are often identified in glosses in instance (ID:5508), notably: rNgog Blo ldan shes rab (ID:3786), rGya dmar ba (ID:3834), Phya pa (ID:3831), Dan 'bag pa (ID:3840), gTsang nag pa (ID:3839), Me tig pa (ID:4207), etc.
alternative_names:
rtog ge rigs pa'i brgyan gyi snying po
bod snga rabs pa'i tshad ma'i spyi don
name: rtog ge rigs pa'i rgyan gyi snying po

A "rtsod rigs la 'bru 'joms" is reported by Ral gri in the list of his compositions (ID:7112), along with a "sa bcad" and "ti ka" on the same work. The "sa bcad" likely corresponds to work (ID:4949) and the "ti ka" to (ID:4951).
In this catalogue, the expression "'bru 'joms" (word for word commentary) is also used for a work related to the Sambandha­parīkṣā­prakaraṇa (ID:3775), which could be work (ID:5900). In that case the entry "rtsod rigs la 'bru 'joms" might also be referring to a set of explanatory annotations written as interlinear notes to the base text. No such work is currently extant.
See also [FZ6N88AU]: 409.
name: rtsod pa'i rigs pa la 'bru 'joms

comments:
Extensive commentary on the Vādanyāya (ID:3777) with numerous references to the interpretations of Vinītadeva (ID:5534) and Śāntarakṣita (ID:3732) as well as to the lost commentary by Śaṅkaranandana (ID:5552).
One of Ral gri's three works on the Vādanyāya according to the list of his writings (ID:7112). See also [FZ6N88AU]: 409.
alternative_names:
rtsod pa'i rigs pa rgyan gyi me tog
rtsod rigs kyi ti ka
ba da na ya a laM ka ra puSH pa
vādanyāyālaṃkārapuṣpa
rtsod rig rgyan gyi me tog
name: rtsod rigs rgyan gyi me tog

Colophon of instance (ID:7312), fol. 52a6: sangs rgyas kyi bstan pa la rim gyis 'jug pa'i tshul zhes bya ba b+hi k+SHu badz+ra ra dzas sbyar ba rdzogs so ||.", 'confidence': 'Positive', 'start': None, 'end': None}]
comments:
In instance (ID:4473), the colophon ascribes the work to Gro lung pa, and names gSang phu as place of composition. As noted in [8SV48WK2] for the item corresponding to (ID:4473), the authorship is debatable, as the colophon stylistically differs from the colophons of the other works by Gro lung pa.
As noticed by Nishizawa ([A629CP5J]: 21, n. 35), the same work is attributed in the bKa' brgyud school to Phag mo gru pa (ID:3856) and included in his collected works (see the colophon of instance (ID:7308) and (ID:7191), (ID:7310), (ID:7309)). See also the colophon of (ID:7312) which names the author Vajrarāja, the Sanskrit equivalent of rDo rje rgyal po.
If the work were by Gro lung pa, it could corresponds to the "bstan rim bsdus" listed  by A khu ching shes rab rgya mtsho in his Tho yig ([5RXEUKD9]: 515, No. 11108: gro lung pa'i bstan rim rgyas bsdus gnyis). However, Jackson's analysis of its contents ([AXC5KZK3]: 233-235) supports the attribution to Phag mo gru pa, as it concludes that "this work is certainly a bstan rim of the early bKa' brgyud tradition, and it represents the sort of adaptation one might expect of the basic bstan rim structure to the demands of a more strictly practice- and meditation-oriented tradition, namely rJe sGam po pa's Mahāmudrā."
Some instances do not name an author in the colophon, see (ID:7309) and (ID:7311), which are however included in collections of Phag mo gru pa's works.
alternative_names:
bstan rim chen mo bsdu 'am lam rim
dge ba'i bshes gnyen chen po gro lung pa'i bstan rim chen mo'i don bsdu'am lam rim
blo sbyong
lam rim
name: sangs rgyas kyi bstan pa la rims kyis 'jug pa'i tshul

comments:
Commentary on Haribhadra’s Abhisamayālaṃkāravṛtti (ID:3711), with references to an anonymous “Spiritual teacher,” to Jo bo 'bum pa (ID:5611), as well as to Atiśa (ID:3745), 'Brom (ID:3827), Zangs kar (ID:3944), Khyung po (ID:4294), an unidentified "mda'" (ID:4303) and "jo bo a sya/pya" (ID:6944), and about 50 times to "lo tsha ba," i.e. rNgog Blo ldan shes rab (ID:3786). 
The author claims to have followed the teaching of his Spiritual teachers in composing the work on request of his disciples and students.

This work probably corresponds to one of the three commentaries on the Abhisamayālaṃkāra (ID:3706) by Khu Shes rab brtson 'grus listed in the Tho yig, see (ID:6532), (ID:6533), (ID:6534).
alternative_names:
khu shes rab brtson 'grus kyis mdzad pa'i shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa'i man ngag gi bstan bcos mngon par rtogs pa'i rgyan gyi 'grel ba'i tshig dang don gsal bar bshad pa
shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa’i man ngag gi bstan bcos mngon par rtogs pa'i rgyan gyi 'grel ba'i tshig dang don gsal bar bshad pa
mngon par rtogs pa'i rgyan gyi 'grel pa'i bshad pa
shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa'i man ngag gi bstan bcos mngon par rtogs pa'i rgyan ces bya ba'i 'grel pa tshig don rab gsal
name: shes rab gyi pha rol du phyin pa'i man ngag gi bstan chos mngon par rtogs pa’i rgyan ces bya ba'i 'grel pa'i tshig dang don gsal bar bshad pa

comments:
The title of the text in the colophon and section colophons indicate that it is a commentary on the Abhisamayālaṅkāravṛtti (ID:3711). The discussion on the title of the base text (see (ID:4454), fol. 35b6) refers to the Tibetan expressions corresponding to the Sanskrit "prajñāpāramita," "upadeśa," "śāstra,"  "abhisamaya," "ālaṃkāra." It does not explain the word "vṛtti," but goes stating "'grel pa 'di la don gsum ste...".
The end of the text systematically comments on the words of Haribhadra's Vṛtti, and large portions are commented before that (such as the dgos 'brel section). It remains to be established if the whole Vṛtti is commented upon in the body of the text. Also referred to is Haribhadra’s Abhisamayālaṅkārālokā (ID:3709) – referred to as the “large commentary” ('grel chen) - although the author frequently disagrees with Haribhadra's interpretation - and the commentaries of Bhadantavimuktisena (ID:5548) and Āryavimuktisena (ID:3708), and  the views of “’bum pa” (Sthirapala (ID:5611).
Also mentioned in the text are notably the views of Dharmottara (ID:3780), Atiśa (ID:3745), 'Brom ston (ID:3827), an unidentified "dge bshes," as well as those of lesser known figures.
 
In the incipit, the author refers to the teaching of Blo ldan shes rab (ID:3786) - to whom the numerous references to "maha/mahA" seem to refer - Rin chen grags (ID:3809), and Shes rab 'bar (ID:3807). The latter is also mentioned in the closing verses.

The introductory section gives the lineage of Prajñāpāramitā. The author lists Indic commentators’ names up to Ratnākaraśānti, Prajñākaramati, Ku lan ta, and Ratnakīrti, but does not refer to Abhayākaragupta's Marmakaumudī.

comments:
Concise guide commenting on the Abhisamayālaṅkāra (ID:3706) via Haribhadra’s commentary, the Abhisamayālaṅkāranāmaprajñāpāramitopadeśaśāstravṛtti (ID:3711), the translation of which rNgog blo ldan shes rab revised together with the Indian Paṇḍit dPal go mi ’chi med. 
It is the earliest known Tibetan commentary on the Abhisamayālaṅkāra.

This work probably corresponds to the "don bdus" listed by several Tibetan scholars (see [BAQ9MH4T]: 202) and the "phar phyin Tik chung" listed in A khu ching Shes rab rgya mtsho's Tho yig ([5RXEUKD9]: 528, No. 11471). A "rnam bshad" is also listed, which is not extant  (ID:6050).

The author mentions the views of other scholars five times without naming them; three of these references are probably to Indian scholars.

The work was preserved in two different blockprints (ID:5591)(ID:5592) and a manuscript (ID:4434).

comments:
Incomplete commentary on the Abhisamayālaṃkāra­ (ID:3706). Features abundant use of "chos can...thal/te...phyir" arguments, including also the use of the pronoun "khyod" as a variable.
Although grouped with works by rNgog Blo ldan shes rab (ID:3786), the latter does not appear to have been the author. In particular, the above-mentioned features are not found in other works of rNgog Blo ldan shes rab.
Discussed in [DQZ4IIQZ]: 59 (170) and 76-78 (151-153).

comments:
Commentary based on another commentary by someone referred to as "Jo bo" composed in "bsam yangs" (maybe for bSam yas?). The author refers to the interpretation by 'Brom ston (ID:6284) and other Tibetan scholars (referred to as “dags po” and “khyung po”). Contains a number of Sanskrit expressions transcribed in Tibetan (e.g., ’bu dha, bo de sa dha, lo ga).
This work may correspond to the "phar phyin" listed in the Tho yig, see (ID:6536).

shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa'i mdo'i rgya cher ’grel ba zhes pa shes rab snying po'i 'grel pa
shes snying gyi rgya cher 'grel

comments:
This may correspond to the work listed by A khu ching shes rab rgya mtsho in his Tho yig ([5RXEUKD9]: 529, No. 11503: [ar byang chub ye shes kyi] mdo sdud pa).
The explanation of the words of the base text is preceded by an introduction that includes an outline of Prajñāpāramitā literature. The author refers to other commentaries on the text (one referred to as “new commentary”), and to the interpretation of “lo tsa ba” (rNgog Blo ldan
shes rab) and “’bum” (i.e., ’Bum phrag gsum pa, brTan skyong/Sthirapāla), and claims to have followed mainly the commentary of Buddhaśrījñāna.

shes rab pha rol tu phyin pa sdud pa tshigs su bcad pa'i rnam par bshad pa
sher phyin gyi bshad sbyar
ar byang chub ye shes kyis slob dpon sangs rgyas ye shes zhabs kyi 'grel ba'i rjes su 'brangs nas mdzad pa'i mdo sdud pa'i Tik+ka
name: shes rab pha rol phyin pa sdud pa tshigs su bcad pa'i rnam par bshad pa

comments:
The incipit presents this work as a "don bsdus pa" of the bCom ldan 'das ma shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa'i snying po rgya cher bshad pa (ID:3713), the colophon as a "bshad pa" on the Shes rab snying po'i rgya cher 'grel. 
It constitutes a "don bsdus pa" in the sense of a "concise guide" rather than a "topical outline." The author provides a hierarchized structure for the base text of Vimalamitra, a structure which becomes less clear towards the end of the work. Words from the base text are cited in a somewhat different translation than the canonical one (ascribed to Vimalamitra himself together with the Tibetan translators and revisors Ban de nam mkha’ and Ye shes snying po).

This work probably corresponds to the "don bdus" listed by several Tibetan scholars (see <<Kano 2016 [BAQ9MH4T]>>: 203). A "rnam bshad" is also listed, which is not extant (ID: 6051).

Japanese translation in [ZZD28ASE]: 144-154. Annotated Japanese translation in [MF8XXCWV].
alternative_names:
bcom ldan 'das ma shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa'i snying po rgya cher bshad pa'i don bsdus pa
shes rab snying po'i 'grel ba

comments:
Epistle of instruction regarding the resolve to attain Buddhahood in 28 verses (according to Śākya mchog ldan’s division) of 2, 4 and 6 lines, of 7 syllables (17–27) and 11 syllables (1–16, 28). It was composed for the community of Ru gsum in gTsong kha (ID:5631).
Kano considers the "sPring yig bdud rtsi'i phreng ba" mentioned in an early unpublished biography of 'Phags pa Blo gros rgyal mtshan by rDo rje 'dzin pa Ye shes rgyal mtshan as a part of the teachings transmitted to 'Phags pa by Nyi ma (ID:4136) (see [A62SS59H]: xiii and [BAQ9MH4T]: 207, n. 76) to be identical to this work.
alternative_names:
rngog blo ldan shes rab kyis mdzad pa'i springs yig bdud rtsi'i thig pa
springs yig bdud rtsi'i thig pa
spring yig bdud rtsi'i thigs pa
spring pa'i yi ge bdud rtsi thig le
springs pa'i yi ge bdud rtsi'i thig le
spring yig bdud rtsi'i thigs pa
le kha a mrï ta ti la ka nA ma kArika
spring yig bdud rtsi'i phreng ba
rngog  lo chen po blo ldan shes rab kyi springs yig bdud rtsi'i thig le
le kha a mrï ta ti la ka nA ma kA ri ka
name: spring yig bdud rtsi'i thig pa

'tei_refs': '', 'support_notes': '', 'confidence': 'Positive', 'start': None, 'end': None}]
comments:
In view of the number of preserved folios of instance (ID:6113), this appears to be a concise guide, distinct from the topical outline (ID:6072).
This work could correspond to the "don bdus" listed by several Tibetan scholars (see <<Kano 2016 [BAQ9MH4T]>>: 204). 
A "rnam bshad" is also listed, which is not extant (ID: 6074). The latter is probably the commentary cited by bSod nams rtse mo (ID:3848) in work (ID:6832) (see [5U8AUKRL]: 287-288).
name: spyod 'jug don bsdus pa

comments:
A khu ching shes rab rgya mtsho reports in his Tho yig a topical outline by Nyang bran (ID:3844) - see work (ID:3844) - ([5RXEUKD9]: 514, No. 11068: nyang bran chos kyi seng+ge'i (bslab btus dang) spyod 'jug gi 'grel pa) and one by Phya pa (ID:3831) - see work (ID:4488) - ([5RXEUKD9]: 514, no. 11076: phya pa chos seng gi spyod 'jug Tik+ka).

Instances (ID:6556) and instances (ID:4487) feature similar but not identical topical outlines of the base text, and in both the author is named as "dge slong chos kyi seng ge" in the colophon. This raises the identification of instance (ID:4487) as representing Phya pa's work and of instance (ID:6556) as representing that of Nyang bran (ID:3844).
name: spyod 'jug gi 'grel

pa".', 'confidence': 'Positive', 'start': None, 'end': None}]
comments:
The expression "legs bshad bsdus pa'i tshul" in the incipit recalls the title of gTsang nag pa brtson 'grus seng ge (ID:3839)'s commentary (ID:4559), but the contents are different.
The author mentions that he summarizes the teachings of "rngog" (ID:3786), "phya pa" (ID:3831) and "nyang ran" (for nyang bran) (ID:3844) or (ID:3876) (both of whom wrote commentaries on the Bodhicaryāvatāra).
The initial verses and part of the beginning of the text finds a literal equivalent in work (ID:4712) by Gro ston (ID:3880), who had been gTsang nag pa's student.
alternative_names: spyod 'jug gi bshad pa
name: spyod 'jug gi legs bshad bsdus pa

comments:
Instruction on the Buddha nature, without direct citations of the Ratnagotravibhāga (ID:3749).
Discussed in [FUFWUVQQ] and translated on pp. 310-318.

The text ends with the history of the transmission (lo rgyus) of the teaching of the Ratnagotravibhāga (ID:3749) along with the Dharmadharmatāvibhaṅga (ID:5634). The list, which does not include rNgog Blo ldan shes rab (ID:3786), ends with Ze'u Chos kyi rgyal mtshan (ID:6458), preceded by sKyo ston (ID:4052) - considered to be the author of the present work. See [FUFWUVQQ]: 305 and 317-318 and [BAQ9MH4T]: 45-47.
name: theg chen rgyud bla ma'i gdams pa

The author also composed a commentary with the same title (see (ID:6585)).

comments:
Topical outline of the Ratnagotravibhāga (ID:3749), one of the “Five Jewels of Maitreya” (ID:6167). It gives a hierarchical structure for the base text (with an initial fourfold division), to which it refers, in instance (ID:7056), by means of interlinear notes indicating lemmas of the base text in its Tibetan translation.

The structure is almost identical to that of rNgog Blo ldan shes rab’s commentary (ID:4441), with the addition of further subdivisions ([H4UUPDCX], [BAQ9MH4T]: 398).

Colophon: ex70426-04-202313.40
alternative_names:

dge slong phywa pa chos kyi seng ges mdzad pa'i theg pa chen po rgyud bla ma'i bsdus don
name: theg pa chen po rgyud bla ma'i bsdus pa'i don

comments:
Concise guide of the Ratnagotravibhāga (ID:3749). Detailed outline in <<Kano 2016 [BAQ9MH4T]>>, Appendix A. Edition of the first chapter based on (ID:6267) in [TBWSNAM6].

The lists of rNgog Blo ldan shes rab's compositions by several Tibetan scholars mention a "rnam bshad" along with a "don bsdus/bsdus don" (see <<Kano 2016 [BAQ9MH4T]>>: 203). It is unclear whether these refer to a larger and a smaller commentary, or to a commentary and a topical outline.
We assume here, following [BAQ9MH4T]: 203, that the "don bsdus" corresponds to the extant concise guide, and that the larger commentary  (ID:6053) is not extant. It could however be the case that the "rnam bshad" corresponds to the extant concise guide, and the "bsdus don" to the extant topical outline (ID:6106).
If it is indeed rNgog Lo's smaller commentary, it can be identified with the "Tik chung" listed in A khu ching shes rab rgya mtsho's Tho yig ([5RXEUKD9]: 522, No. 11316: rgyud bla ma'i Tik chung).

According to 'Gos lo tsA ba (ID:5839), the work inspired Gro lung pa's and Zhang tshes spong's commentaries. See [7V8MZYAI]: 4 (rngog gis rgyud bla ma'i 'grel pa la TI kA chung yang mdzad cing | de la brten nas gro lung pa dang | zhang tshes kyis kyang TI kA mdzad de |).

Colophon: ex1112023-10-18 ex01112025-05-0717-06-56

shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa'i man ngag gi bstan bcos kyi don bsdus pa
TI kA chung

comments:
See [BAQ9MH4T]: 324-336.

This work seems to correspond to the work mentioned by  'Gos lo tsA ba (ID:5839) (see Kano [BAQ9MH4T]: 408) and the "rgyud bla ma'i Tik+ka" listed in A khu ching Shes rab rgya mtsho's Tho yig ([5RXEUKD9]: 523, No. 11336: blo gros mtshungs med [...] mdzad pa'i rgyud bla ma'i Tik+ka).

The work contains numerous references to the views of other scholars, which are however not identified by name except for Phya pa (ID:3831) ([KGJPGEJL]: 109; ex17012025-05-1417-38-38).

The first chapter is edited and translated in [X7GQ6MGV].

comments:
The outline of this commentary on the Ratnagotravibhāga (ID:3749) largely follows that of rNgog Blo ldan shes rab (ID:3786)'s commentary on the same text (ID:4441), which is frequently quoted, and the author adopts rNgog Blo ldan shes rab's interpretation on major issues. See [BAQ9MH4T]: 246-247 and 296-308.

The introductory and closing verses indicate that Phya pa received the teaching of the  Ratna­gotra­vibhāga (ID:3749) from Zhang tshe spong Chos kyi bla ma (ID:3805) ([RMD3GYTC]: 255, n. 21). See ex7052023-07-1814-08-32 and ex705-1104-2023-06-272 

This work seems to correspond to the "Tik+ka" listed A khu ching shes rab rgya mtsho in his Tho yig ([5RXEUKD9]: 523, No. 11320: [phya pa chos seng gi...] rgyud bla ma'i Tik+ka). It could also be intended as part of the entry No. 11474 in A khu ching's list ([5RXEUKD9]: 528, No. 11474: [phya pa chos seng gi] byams chos phyi ma bzhi'i 'grel ba).

Incipit: ex07052025-05-1316-41-09
Colophon: ex705-1104-2023-06-28

comments:
This work could correspond to either the "bsdus pa che ba" or the "bsdus pa chung ba" mentioned in the list of Ral gri's writings (ID:7112).
In spite of the parallels with Ral gri's epistemological summary (ID:4994), there are notable divergences between the views upheld in the two works.

comments:
Part of an epistemological work. The text starts on fol. 75 in instance (ID:4774), suggesting that it is part of a longer treatise. The initial discussion addresses the number of valid cognitions, the definition of valid cognition and its object. The text ends on a discussion on the certitude of co-apprehension (lhan cig dmigs nges). The available portion of the work covers in particular the definition of the objects of cognition (yul kyi mtshan nyid) and the different sorts of objects (yul kyi dbye ba), of which it distinguishes the three, gzung yul, zhen yul, 'jug yul.

[Z5WBK2VV]: 66 reports the title "tshad ma rnam 'grel le'u gnyis pa'i 'grel ba." BUDA gives the title "tshad ma rnam 'grel le'u gsum pa'i rnam bshad."
According to [J4L5X9AG]: 434-435, it is a kind of summary rather than a commentary on either the Pramāṇaviniścaya (ID:3774) or the Pramāṇavārttika (ID:3772) - hence the editorial title "tshad ma'i bsdus pa."
The text post-dates 1219, the date of composition of the Tshad ma rigs gter (ID:5564), which is quoted at least once ( ex045032025-05-2015-12-06 ).
It makes numerous references to the interpretation of Devendrabuddhi (ID:5554) and Dharmottara (ID:3780), and to many unidentified figures, likely Tibetan scholars.
alternative_names:
tshad ma rnam 'grel le'u gnyis pa'i 'grel ba
tshad ma'i rnam 'grel le'u gsum pa'i rnam bshad
name: tshad ma'i bsdus pa

relations: [{'id': 2254, 'label': "rgya dmar ba byang chub grags (3834) author of tshad ma'i bsdus pa (5975)", 'subj': {'url': 'https://tibschol.acdh-ch-dev.oeaw.ac.at/apis/api/apis_ontology.person/3834/', 'label': 'rgya dmar ba byang chub grags (3834)', 'content_type_key': 'apis_ontology.person', 'content_type_name': 'person'}, 'obj': {'url': 'https://tibschol.acdh-ch-dev.oeaw.ac.at/apis/api/apis_ontology.work/5975/', 'label': "tshad ma'i bsdus pa (5975)", 'content_type_key': 'apis_ontology.work', 'content_type_name': 'work'}, 'end_date_to': None, 'end_date_from': None, 'end_date_sort': None, 'start_date_to': None, 'start_date_from': None, 'start_date_sort': None, 'zotero_refs': "[5RXEUKD9]: 674, No. 11810 (in an annotation): tshad ma'i bsdus pa kha shas.", 'tei_refs': '', 'support_notes': '', 'confidence': 'Positive', 'start': None, 'end': None}]

name: tshad ma'i bsdus pa

relations: [{'id': 2255, 'label': "dan bag pa smra ba'i seng ge (3840) author of tshad ma'i bsdus pa (5976)", 'subj': {'url': 'https://tibschol.acdh-ch-dev.oeaw.ac.at/apis/api/apis_ontology.person/3840/', 'label': "dan bag pa smra ba'i seng ge (3840)", 'content_type_key': 'apis_ontology.person', 'content_type_name': 'person'}, 'obj': {'url': 'https://tibschol.acdh-ch-dev.oeaw.ac.at/apis/api/apis_ontology.work/5976/', 'label': "tshad ma'i bsdus pa (5976)", 'content_type_key': 'apis_ontology.work', 'content_type_name': 'work'}, 'end_date_to': None, 'end_date_from': None, 'end_date_sort': None, 'start_date_to': None, 'start_date_from': None, 'start_date_sort': None, 'zotero_refs': None, 'tei_refs': None, 'support_notes': None, 'confidence': 'Positive', 'start': None, 'end': None}]
comments:
This work is not extant. 
It was available in the 15th century, as 'Gos lo tsA ba gzhon nu dpal (ID:5839) consulted it and reports that it contained refutation of Phya pa's (ID:3831) views on the infinity of time and atoms ([R894SIKE]: 407).
It is listed by A khu ching shes rab rgya mtsho in his Tho yig ([5RXEUKD9]: 674, no. 11811: dan 'bag smra seng ge tshad ma'i bsdus pa).
name: tshad ma'i bsdus pa

comments:
This epistemological summary was composed prior to the author's commentary on the Pramāṇaviniścaya (ID:4942), which refers to it twice ([FZ6N88AU]: 409).
It was probably composed by 1282 and is cited by Śākya mchog ldan (ID:6276) and Go rams pa (ID:6758) ([CTQMVBPR]: 27, n. 14).


This work probably corresponds to either the "bsdus pa che ba" or the "bsdus pa chung ba" mentioned in the list of Ral gri's writings (ID:7112). The other summary could be work (ID:5526). 

In spite of the parallels between (ID:4944) and (ID:5526), there are notable divergences between the views upheld in the two works.

The work is listed in A khu ching's Tho yig ([5RXEUKD9]: No. 13429).

Its colophon states that it relies on the oral tradition of Dānaśīla (ID:6032) ([CTQMVBPR]: 34).

name: tshad ma'i bstan bcos sde bdun rgyan gyi me tog

comments:
The work is discussed in [FZ6N88AU], and [MGPRHX73] discusses its authorship, identifying the author as 'Jad pa gzhon nu byang chub (ID:3863), a student of 'Jad pa byang chub skyabs (ID:3864), himself a student of Phya pa (ID:3831).
This epistemological summary is one of the best sources for the identification of the Tibetan interpreters referred to in epistemological works, as it names them explicitly (see [FZ6N88AU]: 415-416 for references).
alternative_names: tshad bsdus
name: tshad ma'i de kho na nyid bsdus pa

comments:
Compendium of the author's bla ma (rdo rje dbang grags)'s work (ID: 5958).
The work postdates the contribution of gTsang nag pa (ID:3839), who is mentioned nominally on fol. 9a5 of (ID:5301). 
It mentions the triad "bshad/'chzad/brtsod."

comments:
As the author completed the work in Sa skya (ID:5733), refers to Phyogs glang gsar ma (ID:6828), and follows the Rigs gter (ID:5564), he is to be identified as Blo gros mtshungs med gNas drug pa (ID:4094) rather than Blo gros mtshungs med gSang phu ba (ID:3896).

This work might be the "tshad ma bsdus pa" referred to in the biography of Mi nyag 'Jam dbyangs grags pa ([FEHIEFEB]: 141).
[8H6M69W4], No. 16323 mistakenly indicates "mnga' ris kyi dge ba'i bshes gnyen 'od zer seng ge" as the author, whereas he is the person who offered the paper to write down the text.

The author makes an opposition between the "rigs gter ba" (followers of the Rigs gter (ID:5564)) and the "bsdus par smra ba" (followers of the summaries). He frequently refers anonymously to the views of Tibetan scholars. Only Phya pa (ID:3831) and Chu mig pa (ID:4018) are named explicitly.
alternative_names:
pra mA Na pin dAr tha
pramāṇapindārtha
name: tshad ma'i don bsdus pa

comments:
Composed after 1219 as it cites the Tshad ma rigs gter (ID:5564).

The work in instance (ID:4782) might be incomplete, but an annotation at the end of the text indicates that it has been proofread.
The composition of two sections in the work is ascribed to Bya bral ba rab mchog (ID:6801), but as there is no such indication for the other sections, we take Bya bral to be different from the author of the work.
name: tshad ma'i legs bshad dri med bcud kyi bdud rtsi

comments:
The work was composed after 1219 as it cites the Tshad ma rigs gter (ID: 5564), and possibly after 1300 as it refers to Mokṣākaragupta (ID:5556).
The presentation is a compilation of definitions and typologies organized in 20 topics (which reminds one of the "lessons" in bsdus grwa compositions), which are the same as in work (ID:4767) by Byang chub sems dpa' dz+nya na shrI (ID:4017). See [J4L5X9AG]: 435.
The author only presents his own system and does not confront his views with those of other thinkers. The work contains numerous citations from Indian sources.
alternative_names: tshad ma'i mtshan nyid rigs pa'i sgo 'byed
name: tshad ma'i mtshan nyid bsdus pa rigs pa'i sgo 'byed pa

comments:
Short digest of epistemology. It does not contain any reference to the views of other Tibetan scholars apart from the mention of "contemporary logicians" (deng sang gyi rtog ge ba rnams) upholding a five-fold typology of non-valid cognition (ex2442025-02-0414-36-25).
The author cites the Madhyamakāvatāra (ID:3726) and the Satyadvayavibhaṅgakārikā (ID:5916) at the beginning of the work, and Atiśa's (ID:3745) Satyadvayāvatāra (ID:6040) at the end.
The epistemological system presented is akin to that of Phya pa (ID:3831), but with some features that find an echo in 13th-century works (in particular by bCom ldan ral gri (ID:4006)), whereas the only available instance (ID:4764) has several archaic features.

Incipit: ex044032025-05-2118-25-44
Conclusion: ex44032023-07-2514-44-09
Colophon: ex44032023-07-2514-44-10
The colophon is followed by the list of Dharmakīrti's (ID:3773) seven treatises (ID:5553) organized into three major and four minor ones, compared respectively to the body and the limbs (ex044032025-05-2118-15-36).
alternative_names:

tshad ma'i spyi'i skad cung zad bsdus pa
name: tshad ma'i spyi skad cung zad bsdus pa

comments:
The colophon credits Red mda' ba (ID: 6756) as a source for the teaching.

According to Georges B.J. Dreyfus, this is a word commentary (tshig 'grel) on Sa skya paN+Di ta's (ID: 3892) Tshad ma rigs gter (ID: 5564) ([P9VAXVKL]: 2).

comments: Excerpts of this lost work are cited and paraphrased by Glo bo mkhan chen. It was possibly a work in verse, to which lDong ston did not write a commentary. The extant fragments do not prove that lDong ston's treatise was a commentary on the Tshad ma rigs gter (ID:5564); it may have been an independent work of epistemology, however engaging with Sa skya Paṇḍita’s views. See [MKQ6FJV7]: 54.
name: tshad ma rigs pa'i snang ba

comments:
Commentary on the Pramāṇavārttikakārikā (ID:3772) based on lectures by gNas lnga rig pa'i paṇ chen Chos kyi rgyal mtshan dpal bzang po (ID:6059) (perhaps Bo don paṇ chen Phyogs las rnam rgyal (ID:6058)) and Blo gros chos kyi seng ge (ID:6058).
The author only refers to Indian commentators and does not mention the views of other Tibetan interpreters.

comments:
Split into four sections in his Collected Works and split into three "works" on BDRC.
A manuscript of two chapters of this work is reported in the list of ancient manuscripts preserved at sNye mo bye mkhar chos sde. See [HMSTSJ7Q]: 37, pod 9, no. 1: mkhas grub dge legs dpal bzang gi tshad ma rnam 'grel rigs pa'i rgya mtsho las le'u gsum pa dang bzhin pa |
alternative_names:
tshad ma rnam 'grel gyi rgya cher bshad pa rigs pa'i rgya mtsho las rang don le'u'i rnam bshad
tshad ma rnam 'grel gyi rgya chen bshad pa rigs pa'i rgya mtsho las mngon sum le'u'i rnam bshad
tshad ma rnam 'grel gyi rgya cher bshad pa rigs pa'i rgya mtsho las gzhan don le'u'i rnam bshad
name: tshad ma rnam 'grel gyi TIk chen rig pa'i rgya mtsho
